5.text: >>Roberts: Handa ka na bang manumpa, Senador ?

8.text: >>Roberts: Ako, si Barack Hussein Obama, ay nanunumpa

12.text: >>Obama: Ako, si Barack Hussein Obama, ay nanunumpa

15.text: >>Roberts: na tutupdan ko ang opisina ng Pangulo sa Estados Unidos ng tapat

24.text: >>Roberts:  tapat ang opisina ng Pangulo ng Estados Unidos

26.text: >>Obama: ang opisina ng Pangulo ng Estados Unidos ng tapat

28.text: >>Roberts: at, sa lubos ng aking kakayahan

30.text: >>Obama: at, sa lubos ng aking kakayahan

31.text: >>Roberts:panatilihin, protektahan at ipagtanggol ang Saligang Batas ng Estados Unidos

35.text: >>panatilihin, protektahan at ipagtanggol ang Saligang Batas ng Estados Unidos

117.text: >>Feinstein: Malaking karangalan sa aking ipakilala sa inyo ang ika 44 na Pangulo ng Estados Unidos, eto si Barack Obama.

161.text: Nakatayo ako dito ngayon puno ng pagpapakumbaba sa

169.text: gawaing hinaharap natin, nagpapasalamat sa tiwalang ginawad,

174.text: randam ang sakripisyo ng ating mga ninuno.

178.text: Pinasasalamatan ko si Pangulong Bush sa kanyang

187.text: serbisyo sa ating bansa, ganun din sa pagbibigay

192.text: at kooperasyong pinakita nya sa proseso ng transisyon.

193.text: Apatnapu't apat nang Amerikano ang sumumpa bilang Pangulo.

200.text: Ang mga talumpati'y binigkas sa gitna ng tumataas na alon

205.text: ng kayamanan at  tahimik na tubig ng kapayapaan.

209.text: Ngunit, madalas din, na ang panunumpang ito'y

214.text: ginawa sa makulimlim na ulap at malakas na bagyo.

217.text: Sa mga pagkakataong ganito, nagpatuloy na sumulong ang Amerika di

223.text: lang dahil sa galing o pananaw ng mga nasa mataas na poder,

225.text: ngunit dahil Tayo ang Sambayanan ay nanatiling tapat sa mga adhikain ng ating mga

231.text: Tagapagtatag at masunurin sa mga dokumento ng Pagkakatatag.

239.text: Kaya't ganito dapat para sa henerasyong ito ng mga Amerikano.

244.text: Na nasa krisis tayo ngayo'y naiintindihan ng lahat.

249.text: Ang bayan natin ay nasa gitna ng digmaan,

253.text: laban sa malawak na alyansa ng karahasan at galit.

255.text: Our economy is badly weakened, a consequence of greed and irresponsibility

260.text: on the part of some, but also our collective failure to make hard choices

265.text: and prepare the nation for a new age.

269.text: Homes have been lost; jobs shed; businesses shuttered.

273.text: Our health care is too costly; our schools fail too many;

276.text: and each day brings further evidence

279.text: that the ways we use energy strengthen our adversaries

285.text: These are the indicators of crisis, subject to data and statistics.

292.text: Less measurable but no less profound is a sapping of confidence

297.text: across our land - a nagging fear that America's decline is inevitable,

304.text: and that the next generation must lower its sights.

309.text: Today I say to you that the challenges we face are real.

313.text: They are serious and they are many.

316.text: They will not be met easily or in a short span of time.

320.text: But know this, America - they will be met.

330.text: On this day, we gather because we have chosen hope over fear,

335.text: unity of purpose over conflict and discord.

340.text: On this day, we come to proclaim an end to the petty grievances

345.text: and false promises, the recriminations and worn out dogmas,

350.text: that for far too long have strangled our politics.

354.text: We remain a young nation, but in the words of Scripture,

359.text: the time has come to set aside childish things.

364.text: The time has come to reaffirm our enduring spirit;

367.text: to choose our better history; to carry forward that precious gift,

372.text: that noble idea, passed on from generation to generation:

375.text: the God-given promise that all are equal, all are free,

380.text: and all deserve a chance to pursue their full measure of happiness.

392.text: In reaffirming the greatness of our nation,

397.text: we understand that greatness is never a given.

403.text: Our journey has never been one of short cuts or settling for less.

407.text: It has not been the path for the faint-hearted -

410.text: for those who prefer leisure over work,

412.text: or seek only the pleasures of riches and fame.

417.text: Rather, it has been the risk-takers, the doers, the makers of things -

421.text: some celebrated but more often men and women obscure in their labor,

426.text: who have carried us up the long,

429.text: rugged path towards prosperity and freedom.

433.text: For us, they packed up their few worldly possessions and traveled

437.text: across oceans in search of a new life.

441.text: For us, they toiled in sweatshops and settled the West;

445.text: endured the lash of the whip and plowed the hard earth.

450.text: For us, they fought and died, in places like Concord

454.text: and Gettysburg, Normandy and Khe Sahn.

459.text: Time and again, these men and women struggled and sacrificed

463.text: and worked until their hands were raw so that we might live a better life.

468.text: They saw America as bigger than the sum of our individual ambitions;

472.text: greater than all the differences of birth or wealth or faction.

477.text: This is the journey we continue today.

481.text: We remain the most prosperous, powerful nation on Earth.

485.text: Our workers are no less productive than when this crisis began.

489.text: Our minds are no less inventive, our goods and services no less needed

493.text: than they were last week or last month or last year.

501.text: But our time of standing pat, of protecting narrow interests

505.text: and putting off unpleasant decisions - that time has surely passed.

511.text: Starting today, we must pick ourselves up, dust ourselves off,

515.text: and begin again the work of remaking America.

525.text: For everywhere we look, there is work to be done.

530.text: The state of our economy calls for action, bold and swift,

534.text: and we will act - not only to create new jobs,

537.text: but to lay a new foundation for growth.

540.text: We will build the roads and bridges, the electric grids and digital lines

544.text: that feed our commerce and bind us together.

548.text: We will restore science to its rightful place,

552.text: to raise health care's quality and lower its cost.

555.text: We will harness the sun and the winds and the soil

559.text: to fuel our cars and run our factories.

561.text: And we will transform our schools and colleges and universities

566.text: to meet the demands of a new age.

570.text: And all this we will do.

572.text: Now, there are some who question the scale of our ambitions -

579.text: who suggest that our system cannot tolerate too many big plans.

586.text: For they have forgotten what this country has already done;

590.text: what free men and women can achieve when imagination is joined

594.text: to common purpose, and necessity to courage.

599.text: What the cynics fail to understand is

601.text: that the ground has shifted beneath them -

604.text: that the stale political arguments that have consumed us

606.text: for so long no longer apply.

610.text: The question we ask today is not whether our government is too big

613.text: or too small, but whether it works - whether it helps families find jobs

618.text: at a decent wage, care they can afford, a retirement that is dignified.

623.text: Where the answer is yes, we intend to move forward.

627.text: Where the answer is no, programs will end.

631.text: And those of us who manage the public's dollars will be held to account -

635.text: to spend wisely, reform bad habits, and do our business in the light

639.text: of day - because only then can we restore the vital trust

643.text: between a people and their government.

648.text: Nor is the question before us whether the market is a force

654.text: Its power to generate wealth and expand freedom is unmatched,

659.text: but this crisis has reminded us that without a watchful eye,

663.text: the market can spin out of control - the nation cannot prosper long

668.text: when it favors only the prosperous.

670.text: The success of our economy has always depended not just on the size

675.text: of our Gross Domestic Product, but on the reach of our prosperity;

679.text: on the ability to extend opportunity to every willing heart -

684.text: not out of charity, but because it is the surest route to our common good.

695.text: As for our common defense, we reject as false the choice

701.text: between our safety and our ideals.

705.text: Our Founding Fathers, faced with perils that we can scarcely imagine,

712.text: drafted a charter to assure the rule of law and the rights of man,

717.text: a charter expanded by the blood of generations.

721.text: Those ideals still light the world,

723.text: and we will not give them up for expedience's sake.

729.text: And so to all the other peoples and governments who are watching today,

734.text: from the grandest capitals to the small village where my father was born:

738.text: know that America is a friend of each nation and every man, woman,

742.text: and child who seeks a future of peace and dignity,

745.text: and we are ready to lead once more.

764.text: Recall that earlier generations faced down fascism and communism not just

769.text: with missiles and tanks, but with the sturdy alliances

775.text: They understood that our power alone cannot protect us,

778.text: nor does it entitle us to do as we please.

780.text: Instead, they knew that our power grows through its prudent use;

785.text: our security emanates from the justness of our cause,

788.text: the force of our example, the tempering qualities

796.text: We are the keepers of this legacy.

798.text: Guided by these principles once more, we can meet those new threats

803.text: that demand even greater effort - even greater cooperation

809.text: We will begin to responsibly leave Iraq to its people,

812.text: and forge a hard-earned peace in Afghanistan.

816.text: With old friends and former foes,

818.text: we will work tirelessly to lessen the nuclear threat,

821.text: and roll back the specter of a warming planet.

825.text: We will not apologize for our way of life,

828.text: nor will we waver in its defense,

831.text: and for those who seek to advance their aims by inducing terror

834.text: and slaughtering innocents, we say to you now that our spirit is stronger

838.text: and cannot be broken; you cannot outlast us, and we will defeat you.

856.text: For we know that our patchwork heritage is a strength, not a weakness.

862.text: We are a nation of Christians and Muslims,

870.text: We are shaped by every language and culture,

873.text: drawn from every end of this Earth;

875.text: and because we have tasted the bitter swill of civil war and segregation,

880.text: and emerged from that dark chapter stronger and more united,

883.text: we cannot help but believe that the old hatreds shall someday pass;

887.text: that the lines of tribe shall soon dissolve;

890.text: that as the world grows smaller, our common humanity shall reveal itself;

894.text: and that America must play its role in ushering in a new era of peace.

899.text: To the Muslim world, we seek a new way forward,

904.text: based on mutual interest and mutual respect.

908.text: To those leaders around the globe who seek to sow conflict,

913.text: or blame their society's ills on the West -

915.text: know that your people will judge you

917.text: on what you can build, not what you destroy.

922.text: To those who cling to power through corruption and deceit and the silencing

930.text: of dissent, know that you are on the wrong side of history;

934.text: but that we will extend a hand if you are willing to unclench your fist.

939.text: To the people of poor nations, we pledge to work alongside you

946.text: to make your farms flourish and let clean waters flow;

950.text: to nourish starved bodies and feed hungry minds.

954.text: And to those nations like ours that enjoy relative plenty,

958.text: we say we can no longer afford indifference

963.text: nor can we consume the world's resources without regard to effect.

968.text: For the world has changed, and we must change with it.

974.text: As we consider the road that unfolds before us,

979.text: we remember with humble gratitude those brave Americans who,

984.text: at this very hour, patrol far-off deserts and distant mountains.

988.text: They have something to tell us, just as the fallen heroes who lie

995.text: in Arlington whisper through the ages.

999.text: We honor them not only because they are the guardians of our liberty,

1003.text: but because they embody the spirit of service;

1007.text: a willingness to find meaning in something greater than themselves.

1012.text: And yet, at this moment - a moment that will define a generation -

1018.text: it is precisely this spirit that must inhabit us all.

1024.text: For as much as government can do and must do, it is ultimately the faith

1029.text: and determination of the American people upon which this nation relies.

1034.text: It is the kindness to take in a stranger when the levees break,

1038.text: the selflessness of workers who would rather cut their hours

1041.text: than see a friend lose their job which sees us through our darkest hours.

1046.text: It is the firefighter's courage to storm a stairway filled with smoke,

1050.text: but also a parent's willingness to nurture a child,

1062.text: The instruments with which we meet them may be new.

1066.text: But those values upon which our success depends - honesty and hard work,

1072.text: courage and fair play, tolerance and curiosity,

1077.text: loyalty and patriotism - these things are old.

1089.text: They have been the quiet force of progress throughout our history.

1094.text: What is demanded then is a return to these truths.

1097.text: What is required of us now is a new era of responsibility - a recognition,

1104.text: on the part of every American, that we have duties to ourselves,

1107.text: our nation, and the world, duties that we do not grudgingly accept

1112.text: but rather seize gladly, firm in the knowledge that there is nothing

1115.text: so satisfying to the spirit, so defining of our character,

1120.text: than giving our all to a difficult task.

1124.text: This is the price and the promise of citizenship.

1128.text: This is the source of our confidence - the knowledge that God calls on us

1136.text: This is the meaning of our liberty and our creed - why men and women

1140.text: and children of every race and every faith can join in celebration

1144.text: across this magnificent mall, and why a man whose father less

1149.text: than sixty years ago might not have been served

1152.text: at a local restaurant can now stand before you to take a most sacred oath.

1168.text: So let us mark this day with remembrance,

1173.text: of who we are and how far we have traveled.

1178.text: In the year of America's birth, in the coldest of months,

1183.text: a small band of patriots huddled by dying campfires

1187.text: on the shores of an icy river.

1194.text: The snow was stained with blood.

1197.text: At a moment when the outcome of our revolution was most in doubt,

1202.text: the father of our nation ordered these words be read to the people:

1207.text: "Let it be told to the future world...that in the depth of winter,

1212.text: when nothing but hope and virtue could survive...that the city

1216.text: and the country, alarmed at one common danger, came forth to meet it."

1222.text: America. In the face of our common dangers, in this winter of our hardship,

1228.text: let us remember these timeless words.

1233.text: With hope and virtue, let us brave once more the icy currents,

1237.text: and endure what storms may come.

1240.text: Let it be said by our children's children

1242.text: that when we were tested we refused to let this journey end,

1246.text: that we did not turn back nor did we falter;

1249.text: and with eyes fixed on the horizon and God's grace upon us,

1253.text: we carried forth that great gift of freedom

1256.text: and delivered it safely to future generations.

1260.text: God bless you, and God bless the United States of America.
